In some cases, people can actually feel the contractions as they occur, especially in the case of movements of the large intestine. Vomiting is an example of the body overriding the usual muscle movements of peristalsis. Peristalsis. a wavelike contraction that propels the contents of tubular organs, for example, the intestine, stomach, and ureters, caudally in animals or in a downward direction in man. Peristalsis is the result of many coordinated contractions of the longitudinal and transverse muscles in the walls of a tubular organ. A single peristaltic wave takes the form of a circular constriction around the lumen that moves along the length of the organ.
